title: Room-temperature superconductor
content:
{{short description|Material which exhibits superconductivity above 0 °C}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2019}}
A '''room-temperature superconductor''' is a material that is capable of exhibiting [[superconductivity]] at [[operating temperature]]s above {{cvt|0|C|K F}}, that is, temperatures that can be reached and easily maintained in an everyday environment. {{As of|2020}}, the material with the highest claimed superconducting temperature is an extremely pressurized [[carbonaceous sulfur hydride]] with a critical transition temperature of +15 °C at 267 GPa.<ref name=Snider>{{cite journal |last1=Snider |first1=Elliot |last2=Dasenbrock-Gammon |first2=Nathan |last3=McBride |first3=Raymond |last4=Debessai |first4=Mathew |last5=Vindana |first5=Hiranya |last6=Vencatasamy |first6=Kevin |last7=Lawler |first7=Keith V. |last8=Salamat |first8=Ashkan |last9=Dias |first9=Ranga P. |title=Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride |journal=Nature |date=15 October 2020 |volume=586 |issue=7829 |pages=373–377 |doi=10.1038/s41586-020-2801-z|pmid=33057222 |bibcode=2020Natur.586..373S |osti=1673473 |s2cid=222823227 }}</ref> On 22 September 2022, the original article reporting superconductivity in the carbonaceous sulfur hydride material was retracted by ''Nature'' journal editorial board due to a non standard, user-defined data analysis, calling into question the scientific validity of the claim.<ref>{{cite journal|title='Something is seriously wrong': Room-temperature superconductivity study retracted|quote=After doubts grew, blockbuster Nature paper is withdrawn over objections of study team|date=26 September 2022|first=Eric|last=Hand|journal=Science|volume=377 |issue=6614 |pages=1474–1475 |doi=10.1126/science.adf0773 |pmid=36173853 |s2cid=252622995 |url=https://www.science.org/content/article/something-seriously-wrong-room-temperature-superconductivity-study-retracted}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi=10.1038/s41586-022-05294-9 | title=Retraction Note: Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride | journal=Nature | date=26 September 2022 | last1=Snider | first1=Elliot | last2=Dasenbrock-Gammon | first2=Nathan | last3=McBride | first3=Raymond | last4=Debessai | first4=Mathew | last5=Vindana | first5=Hiranya | last6=Vencatasamy | first6=Kevin | last7=Lawler | first7=Keith V. | last8=Salamat | first8=Ashkan | last9=Dias | first9=Ranga P. | volume=610 | issue=7933 | page=804 | pmid=36163290 | bibcode=2022Natur.610..804S | s2cid=252544156 | doi-access=free }}</ref>

At [[atmospheric pressure]] the temperature record is still held by [[High-temperature superconductor#Cuprates|cuprates]], which have demonstrated superconductivity at temperatures as high as {{convert|138|K|°C}}.<ref>{{cite journal
 | title = Synthesis and neutron powder diffraction study of the superconductor HgBa<sub>2</sub>Ca<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>8+δ</sub> by Tl substitution
 | journal = Physica C  | volume = 243  | issue = 3–4  | pages = 201–206  | year = 1995
 | doi =  10.1016/0921-4534(94)02461-8|bibcode = 1995PhyC..243..201D | last1 = Dai  | first1 = P.  | last2 = Chakoumakos  | first2 = B.C.  | last3 = Sun  | first3 = G.F.  | last4 = Wong  | first4 = K.W.  | last5 = Xin  | first5 = Y.  | last6 = Lu  | first6 = D.F.  }}</ref>

Although researchers once doubted whether room-temperature superconductivity was actually achievable,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Geballe |first1=T. H. |title=Paths to Higher Temperature Superconductors |journal=Science |date=12 March 1993 |volume=259 |issue=5101 |pages=1550–1551 |doi=10.1126/science.259.5101.1550 |pmid=17733017 |bibcode=1993Sci...259.1550G }}</ref><ref name=almaden>{{cite web |url=https://researcher.watson.ibm.com/researcher/view_project.php?id=3702 |title=Almaden Institute 2012: Superconductivity 297 K – Synthetic Routes to Room Temperature Superconductivity |work=researcher.watson.ibm.com|date=25 July 2016 }}</ref> superconductivity has repeatedly been discovered at temperatures that were previously unexpected or held to be impossible.

Claims of "near-room temperature" transient effects date from the early 1950s. Finding a room temperature superconductor "would have enormous technological importance and, for example, help to solve the world's energy problems, provide for faster computers, allow for novel memory-storage devices, and enable ultra-sensitive sensors, among many other possibilities."<ref name=almaden/><ref>NOVA. Race for the Superconductor. Public TV station WGBH Boston. Approximately 1987.</ref>

{{unsolved|physics|Is it possible to make a material that is a superconductor at room temperature and atmospheric pressure?}}

==Reports==
Since the discovery of [[high-temperature superconductor]]s, several materials have been reported to be room-temperature [[superconductor]]s, although most of these reports have not been confirmed.{{Citation needed|date=October 2020}}

In 2000, while extracting electrons from [[diamond]] during [[ion implantation]] work, Johan Prins claimed to have observed a phenomenon that he explained as room-temperature superconductivity within a [[Phase (matter)|phase]] formed on the surface of oxygen-doped type [[Diamond|IIa diamonds]] in a [[Vacuum|{{nowrap|10<sup>−6</sup> mbar}} vacuum]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Prins |first1=Johan F |title=The diamond vacuum interface: II. Electron extraction from n-type diamond: evidence for superconduction at room temperature |journal=Semiconductor Science and Technology |date=1 March 2003 |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=S131–S140 |doi=10.1088/0268-1242/18/3/319 |bibcode=2003SeScT..18S.131P |s2cid=250881569 }}</ref>

In 2003, a group of researchers published results on high-temperature superconductivity in [[palladium hydride]] (PdH<sub>x</sub>: x>1)<ref name=Tripodi2003>{{Cite journal 
| last1 = Tripodi | first1 = P. 
| last2 = Di Gioacchino | first2 = D. 
| last3 = Borelli | first3 = R. 
| last4 = Vinko | first4 = J. D. 
| title = Possibility of high temperature superconducting phases in PdH 
| doi = 10.1016/S0921-4534(02)02745-4 
| journal = Physica C: Superconductivity 
| volume = 388–389 
| pages = 571–572
| date=May 2003
| bibcode = 2003PhyC..388..571T }}</ref> and an explanation in 2004.<ref name=Tripodi2004>{{Cite journal 
| last1 = Tripodi | first1 = P. 
| last2 = Di Gioacchino | first2 = D. 
| last3 = Vinko | first3 = J. D. 
| title = Superconductivity in PdH: Phenomenological explanation 
| doi = 10.1016/j.physc.2004.02.099 
| journal = Physica C: Superconductivity 
| volume = 408–410 
| pages = 350–352
|date=August 2004
|bibcode = 2004PhyC..408..350T }}</ref> In 2007, the same group published results suggesting a superconducting transition temperature of 260 K.<ref name=Tripodi2007>{{cite journal 
| last1 = Tripodi | first1 = P. 
| last2 = Di Gioacchino | first2 = D. 
| last3 = Vinko | first3 = J. D. 
| title = A review of high temperature superconducting property of PdH system
| doi = 10.1142/S0217979207044524 
| bibcode = 2007IJMPB..21.3343T 
| journal = [[International Journal of Modern Physics#B|International Journal of Modern Physics B]] 
| volume = 21 
| issue = 18&19 
| pages = 3343–3347 
| year = 2007}}</ref> The superconducting critical temperature increases as the density of hydrogen inside the palladium lattice increases. This work has not been corroborated by other groups.

In 2012, an ''[[Advanced Materials]]'' article claimed superconducting behavior of [[graphite]] powder after treatment with pure water at temperatures as high as 300 K and above.<ref>
{{cite journal
|title=Can Doping Graphite Trigger Room Temperature Superconductivity? Evidence for Granular High-Temperature Superconductivity in Water-Treated Graphite Powder
|journal=Advanced Materials
|volume=24
|issue=43
|pages=5826–31
|year=2012
|doi=10.1002/adma.201202219
|pmid=22949348
|last1=Scheike|first1=T.
|last2=Böhlmann|first2=W.
|last3=Esquinazi|first3=P.
|last4=Barzola-Quiquia|first4=J.
|last5=Ballestar|first5=A.
|last6=Setzer|first6=A.
|arxiv=1209.1938|bibcode=2012AdM....24.5826S
|s2cid=205246535
}}</ref>{{Unreliable source?|date=May 2019}} So far, the authors have not been able to demonstrate the occurrence of a clear [[Meissner effect|Meissner]] phase and the vanishing of the material's resistance.

In 2014, an article published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' suggested that some materials, notably YBCO ([[yttrium barium copper oxide]]), could be made to superconduct at room temperature using [[infrared laser]] pulses.<ref>
{{cite journal
|title=Nonlinear lattice dynamics as a basis for enhanced superconductivity in YBa<sub>2</sub>Cu<sub>3</sub>O<sub>6.5</sub>
|first1=R.|last1=Mankowsky
|first2=A.|last2=Subedi
|first3=M.|last3=Först
|first4=S. O.|last4=Mariager
|first5=M.|last5=Chollet
|first6=H. T.|last6=Lemke
|first7=J. S.|last7=Robinson
|first8=J. M.|last8=Glownia
|first9=M. P.|last9=Minitti
|first10=A.|last10=Frano
|first11=M.|last11=Fechner
|first12=N. A. |last12=Spaldin|author12-link=Nicola Spaldin
|first13=T. |last13=Loew
|first14=B. |last14=Keimer
|first15=A. |last15=Georges
|first16=A. |last16=Cavalleri
|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]
|year=2014
|pages=71–73
|volume=516
|issue=7529
|doi=10.1038/nature13875
|pmid=25471882|arxiv = 1405.2266
|bibcode = 2014Natur.516...71M |s2cid=3127527}}</ref>

In 2015, an article published in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' by researchers of the Max Planck Institute suggested that under certain conditions such as extreme pressure {{chem|[[Hydrogen|H]]|2|[[Sulfur|S]]}} transitioned to a superconductive form {{chem|[[Hydrogen|H]]|3|[[Sulfur|S]]}} at 150 GPa (around 1.5 million times atmospheric pressure) in a [[diamond anvil cell]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Drozdov|first1=A. P.|last2=Eremets|first2=M. I.|last3=Troyan|first3=I. A.|last4=Ksenofontov|first4=V.|last5=Shylin|first5=S. I.|date=2015|title=Conventional superconductivity at 203 kelvin at high pressures in the sulfur hydride system|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nature14964|journal=Nature|language=en|volume=525|issue=7567|pages=73–76|doi=10.1038/nature14964|pmid=26280333|issn=0028-0836|arxiv=1506.08190|bibcode=2015Natur.525...73D|s2cid=4468914}}</ref> The critical temperature is {{convert|203|K|°C}} which would be the highest ''T''<sub>c</sub> ever recorded and their research suggests that [[polyhydrides|other hydrogen compounds]] could superconduct at up to {{convert|260|K|°C}} which would match up with the original research of Ashcroft.<ref name=cart15>{{cite journal|last1=Cartlidge|first1=Edwin|title=Superconductivity record sparks wave of follow-up physics|journal=Nature|volume=524|issue=7565|pages=277|date=18 August 2015|doi=10.1038/nature.2015.18191|pmid=26289188|bibcode=2015Natur.524..277C|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref name=GeZhangYao2016>{{Cite journal|last1= Ge|first1=Y. F.|last2=Zhang|first2=F.|last3=Yao|first3=Y. G.|title=First-principles demonstration of superconductivity at {{convert|280|K|°C}} in hydrogen sulfide with low phosphorus substitution|journal=Phys. Rev. B|volume=93|issue=22|pages=224513|year=2016|url=https://zenodo.org/record/1042765|doi = 10.1103/PhysRevB.93.224513 |arxiv=1507.08525|bibcode=2016PhRvB..93v4513G|s2cid=118730557}}</ref>

In 2018, Dev Kumar Thapa and Anshu Pandey from the Solid State and Structural Chemistry Unit of the Indian Institute of Science in Bangalore claimed the observation of superconductivity at ambient pressure and room temperature in films and pellets of a nanostructured material that is composed of silver particles embedded in a gold matrix.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Evidence for Superconductivity at Ambient Temperature and Pressure in Nanostructures|first1=Dev Kumar |last1=Thapa |first2=Anshu |last2=Pandey |arxiv = 1807.08572 |bibcode = 2018arXiv180708572T |year=2018 }}</ref> Due to similar noise patterns of supposedly independent plots and the publication's lack of [[peer review]], the results have been called into question.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/science/iisc-duos-claim-of-ambient-superconductivity-may-have-support-in-theory/article24725793.ece |title=IISc duo's claim of ambient superconductivity may have support in theory |last=Desikan |first=Shubashree |date=18 August 2018 |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |access-date=4 October 2018}}</ref> Although the researchers validated their findings in a later paper in 2019,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/science/finally-iisc-team-confirms-superconductivity-at-room-temperature-pressure/article27246496.ece|title=Finally, IISc team confirms breakthrough in superconductivity at room temperature|first1=R.|last1=Prasad|first2=Shubashree|last2=Desikan|date=25 May 2019|via=www.thehindu.com|newspaper=The Hindu}}</ref> this claim is yet to be verified and confirmed.{{Citation needed|date=October 2020}}

Also in 2018, researchers noted a possible superconducting phase at {{convert|260|K|C}} in [[lanthanum decahydride]] at elevated (200 [[Pascal (unit)|GPa]]) pressure.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Andrew |last=Grant |doi=10.1063/PT.6.1.20180823b |title= Pressurized superconductors approach room-temperature realm |journal = Physics Today |date= 23 August 2018|s2cid=240297717 }}</ref>

In 2019, the material with the highest accepted superconducting temperature was highly pressurized [[lanthanum decahydride]] ({{chem|[[Lanthanum|La]]|[[Hydrogen|H]]|10}}), whose [[transition temperature]] is approximately {{convert|250|K|°C}}.<ref name=hemley>{{cite journal |last1=Somayazulu |first1=M. |last2=Ahart |first2=M. |last3=Mishra |first3=A.K. |last4=Geballe |first4=Z.M. |last5=Baldini |first5=M. |last6=Meng |first6=Y. |last7=Struzhkin |first7=V.V. |last8=Hemley |first8=R.J. |title=Evidence for Superconductivity above 260K in Lanthanum Superhydride at Megabar Pressures |journal=Phys. Rev. Lett. |date=2019 |volume=122 |issue=2 |page=027001 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.122.027001 |pmid=30720326 | arxiv=1808.07695|bibcode=2019PhRvL.122b7001S |s2cid=53622077 }}</ref><ref name=eremets>{{cite journal|doi=10.1038/s41586-019-1201-8|pmid=31118520|title=Superconductivity at 250 K in lanthanum hydride under high pressures|journal=Nature|volume=569|issue=7757|pages=528–531|year=2019|last1=Drozdov|first1=A. P.|last2=Kong|first2=P. P.|last3=Minkov|first3=V. S.|last4=Besedin|first4=S. P.|last5=Kuzovnikov|first5=M. A.|last6=Mozaffari|first6=S.|last7=Balicas|first7=L.|last8=Balakirev|first8=F. F.|last9=Graf|first9=D. E.|last10=Prakapenka|first10=V. B.|last11=Greenberg|first11=E.|last12=Knyazev|first12=D. A.|last13=Tkacz|first13=M.|last14=Eremets|first14=M. I.|arxiv=1812.01561|bibcode=2019Natur.569..528D|s2cid=119231000}}</ref>

In October 2020, room-temperature superconductivity at 288 K (at 15 °C) was reported in a [[carbonaceous sulfur hydride]] at very high pressure (267 GPa) triggered into crystallisation via green laser.<ref>{{cite news|title=Finally, the First Room-Temperature Superconductor|date=October 14, 2020|newspaper=The New York Times|first=Kenneth|last=Chang|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/14/science/superconductor-room-temperature.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Snider |first1=Elliot |last2=Dasenbrock-Gammon |first2=Nathan |last3=McBride |first3=Raymond |last4=Debessai |first4=Mathew |last5=Vindana |first5=Hiranya |last6=Vencatasamy |first6=Kevin |last7=Lawler |first7=Keith V. |last8=Salamat |first8=Ashkan |last9=Dias |first9=Ranga P. |title=Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous sulfur hydride |journal=Nature |date=October 2020 |volume=586 |issue=7829 |pages=373–377 |doi=10.1038/s41586-020-2801-z |pmid=33057222 |bibcode=2020Natur.586..373S |osti=1673473 |s2cid=222823227 }}</ref> The paper has been retracted in 2022 as doubts were raised concerning the statistical methods used by the authors to derive the result.<ref>{{cite news|title='Something is Seriously Wrong':Room-Temperature superconductivity study retracted|date=September 26, 2022|magazine=Science|first=Eric|last=Hand|url=https://www.science.org/content/article/something-seriously-wrong-room-temperature-superconductivity-study-retracted}}</ref>

In March 2021, an announcement reported room-temperature superconductivity in a layered yttrium-palladium-hydron material at 262 K and a pressure of 187 GPa.
Palladium may act as a hydrogen migration catalyst in the material.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://phys.org/news/2021-03-material-superconductive-room-temperature-pressure.html|title = A material that is superconductive at room temperature and lower pressure}}</ref>

In March 2023, superconductivity at a temperature of 294 K, and a pressure of 1 GPa, was reported in a nitrogen-doped [[Lutetium hydride nitride|lutetium hydride]] material.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=The New York Times|title=New Room-Temperature Superconductor Offers Tantalizing Possibilities|author=Kenneth Chang|date=March 8, 2023|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/08/science/room-temperature-superconductor-ranga-dias.html}}</ref> The claim has been met with some skepticism as it was made by the same researchers (see [[Ranga P. Dias]]) that made similar claims retracted by ''Nature'' in 2022<ref>
{{Cite journal
 | url = https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-05742-0
 | title = Evidence of near-ambient superconductivity in a N-doped lutetium hydride
 | first1 = Nathan
 | last1 = Dasenbrock-Gammon
 | first2 = Elliot
 | last2 = Snider
 | first3 = Raymond
 | last3 = McBride
 | first4 = Hiranya
 | last4 = Pasan
 | first5 = Dylan
 | last5 = Durkee
 | first6 = Nugzari
 | last6 = Khalvashi-Sutter
 | first7 = Sasanka
 | last7 = Munasinghe
 | first8 = Sachith E.
 | last8 = Dissanayake
 | first9 = Keith V.
 | last9 = Lawler
 | first10 = Ashkan
 | last10 = Salamat
 | first11 = Ranga P.
 | last11 = Dias
 | date = 9 March 2023
 | journal = Nature
 | volume = 615
 | issue = 7951
 | pages = 244–250
 | via = www.nature.com
 | doi = 10.1038/s41586-023-05742-0
 | pmid = 36890373 
 | s2cid = 257407449
}}</ref><ref>
{{Cite web
 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/superconductor-breakthrough-energy-reddmatter-90dfa165
 | title = The Scientific Breakthrough That Could Make Batteries Last Longer
 | first = Aylin
 | last = Woodward
 | website = WSJ
}}</ref><ref>
{{Cite web
 | url = https://www.science.org/content/article/revolutionary-blue-crystal-resurrects-hope-room-temperature-superconductivity
 | title = 'Revolutionary' blue crystal resurrects hope of room temperature superconductivity
 | website = www.science.org
}}</ref><ref>
{{Cite web
 | title = Room-Temperature Superconductivity Claimed
 | author = Margo Anderson
 | date = March 8, 2023
 | publisher = [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]]
 | website = [[IEEE Spectrum]]
 | url = https://spectrum.ieee.org/room-temperature-superconductor
}}</ref><ref>{{cite web
	| url = https://www.quantamagazine.org/room-temperature-superconductor-discovery-meets-with-resistance-20230308/
	| title = Room-Temperature Superconductor Discovery Meets With Resistance
	| last1 = Wood
	| first1 = Charlie
	| last2 = Savitsky
	| first2 = Zack
	| date = 8 March 2023
	| website = [[Quanta Magazine]]
	| publisher = [[Simons Foundation]]
	| access-date = 2023-03-14
}}</ref> and [[Metallic hydrogen#Claimed observation of solid metallic hydrogen, 2016|claimed observation of solid metallic hydrogen]] in 2016 as well as other allegations.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Garisto |first=Dan |date=2023-03-09 |title=Allegations of Scientific Misconduct Mount as Physicist Makes His Biggest Claim Yet |url=https://physics.aps.org/articles/v16/40 |journal=Physics |language=en |volume=16 |pages=40}}</ref> Dense group IVa hydrides (as the new material) have been previously suggested could be superconductors at lower pressures than metallic hydrogen.<ref name=Ashc2004/><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Ming |first=Xue |last2=Zhang |first2=Ying-Jie |last3=Zhu |first3=Xiyu |last4=Li |first4=Qing |last5=He |first5=Chengping |last6=Liu |first6=Yuecong |last7=Huang |first7=Tianheng |last8=Liu |first8=Gan |last9=Zheng |first9=Bo |last10=Yang |first10=Huan |last11=Sun |first11=Jian |last12=Xi |first12=Xiaoxiang |last13=Wen |first13=Hai-Hu |date=2023-05-11 |title=Absence of near-ambient superconductivity in LuH2±xNy |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06162-w |journal=Nature |language=en |pages=1–3 |doi=10.1038/s41586-023-06162-w |issn=1476-4687}}</ref> First attempts to replicate the results of superconductivity in nitrogen-doped lutetium hydride have failed.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Wilkins |first=Alex |date=17 March 2023 |title='Red matter' superconductor may not be a wonder material after all |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/2364955-red-matter-superconductor-may-not-be-a-wonder-material-after-all/ |access-date= |website=New Scientist |language=en-US}}</ref>

==Theories==
Theoretical work by British physicist [[Neil Ashcroft]] predicted that solid [[metallic hydrogen]] at extremely high pressure (~500 [[Pascal (unit)|GPa]]) should become superconducting at approximately room-temperature because of its extremely high [[speed of sound]] and expected strong [[coupling (physics)|coupling]] between the conduction electrons and the lattice vibrations ([[phonon]]s).<ref name=Ashc1968>
{{cite journal
 |author = Ashcroft, N. W. 
 |title = Metallic Hydrogen: A High-Temperature Superconductor?
 |year = 1968  |journal = [[Physical Review Letters]]
 |volume = 21 |issue=26 |pages = 1748–1749  |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.21.1748
|bibcode = 1968PhRvL..21.1748A }}</ref> This prediction is yet to be experimentally verified, as the pressure to achieve metallic hydrogen is not known but may be on the order of 500 [[Pascal (unit)|GPa]].

A team at [[Harvard University]] has claimed to make metallic hydrogen and reports a pressure of 495 GPa.<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/science/hydrogen-metal-revolution-technology-space-rockets-superconductor-harvard-university-a7548221.html | title=Hydrogen turned into metal in stunning act of alchemy that could revolutionise technology and spaceflight |work=[[The Independent]] |language=en-UK |first=Ian |last=Johnston |date=26 January 2017}}</ref> Though the exact critical temperature has not yet been determined, weak signs of a possible [[Meissner effect]] and changes in magnetic susceptibility at 250 K may have appeared in early magnetometer tests on the original now-lost sample and is being analyzed by the French team working with doughnut shapes rather than planar at the diamond culet tips.<ref>{{Cite arXiv |eprint = 1906.05634|title = Observation of a first order phase transition to metal hydrogen near 425 GPa|last1 = Loubeyre|first1 = Paul|last2 = Occelli|first2 = Florent|last3 = Dumas|first3 = Paul|year = 2019| class=cond-mat.mtrl-sci }}</ref>

In 1964, William A. Little proposed the possibility of high temperature superconductivity in [[organic polymers]].<ref>{{cite journal
 |author = Little, W. A. 
 |title = Possibility of Synthesizing an Organic Superconductor
 |year = 1964  |journal = Physical Review
 |volume = 134 |issue = 6A
 |pages = A1416–A1424  |doi = 10.1103/PhysRev.134.A1416|bibcode = 1964PhRv..134.1416L }}</ref> This proposal is based on the [[exciton]]-mediated electron pairing, as opposed to [[phonon]]-mediated pairing in [[BCS theory]].

In 2004, Ashcroft returned to his idea and suggested that hydrogen-rich compounds can become metallic and superconducting at lower pressures than hydrogen. More specifically, he proposed a novel way to pre-compress hydrogen chemically by examining [[IVa hydride]]s.<ref name=Ashc2004>
{{cite journal
 |author = Ashcroft, N. W. 
 |title = Hydrogen Dominant Metallic Alloys: High Temperature superconductors
 |year = 2004  |journal = [[Physical Review Letters]]
 |volume = 92 |issue=18 |pages = 1748–1749  |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.92.187002|pmid = 15169525
 |bibcode = 2004PhRvL..92r7002A
 }}</ref>

In 2016, research suggested a link between the [[palladium hydride]] containing small impurities of sulfur [[nanoparticle]]s as a plausible explanation for the anomalous transient resistance drops seen during some experiments, and hydrogen absorption by cuprates was suggested in light of the 2015 results in {{chem|link=Hydrogen sulfide|H|2|S}} as a plausible explanation for transient resistance drops or "USO" noticed in the 1990s by Chu ''et al.'' during research after the discovery of [[YBCO]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}<ref>{{Cite thesis|url=https://research-repository.griffith.edu.au/handle/10072/367614|title=Transient High-Temperature Superconductivity in Palladium Hydride |website=[[Griffith University]] |year=2016 |publisher=Griffith University |type=Griffith thesis }}</ref> It is also possible that if the [[bipolaron]] explanation is correct, a normally semiconducting material can transition under some conditions into a superconductor if a critical level of alternating spin coupling in a single plane within the lattice is exceeded; this may have been documented in very early experiments from 1986. The best analogy here would be anisotropic [[magnetoresistance]], but in this case the outcome is a drop to zero rather than a decrease within a very narrow temperature range for the compounds tested similar to "[[re-entrant superconductivity]]".{{citation needed|date=December 2019}}

In 2018, support was found for electrons having anomalous 3/2 [[Spin (physics)|spin states]] in YPtBi.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.sciencealert.com/brand-new-type-of-superconductor-discovered-physics |title=Physicists Just Discovered an Entirely New Type of Superconductivity |first=Fiona |last=MacDonald |date=9 April 2018 |work=ScienceAlert}}</ref> Though YPtBi is a relatively low temperature superconductor, this does suggest another approach to creating superconductors.

It was also discovered that many superconductors, including the cuprates and iron [[pnictide]]s, have two or more competing mechanisms fighting for dominance ([[Charge density wave]]){{citation needed|date=December 2019}} and excitonic states so, as with organic light emitting diodes and other quantum systems, adding the right spin catalyst may by itself increase ''T''<sub>c</sub>. A possible candidate would be [[iridium]] or [[gold]] placed in some of the adjacent molecules or as a thin surface layer so the correct mechanism then propagates throughout the entire lattice similar to a phase transition. As yet, this is speculative; some efforts have been made, notably adding [[lead]] to [[BSCCO]], which is well known to help promote high ''T''<sub>c</sub> phases by chemistry alone. However, [[relativistic effects]] similar to those found in lead-acid batteries might be responsible suggesting that a similar mechanism in [[mercury (element)|mercury]]- or [[thallium]]-based cuprates may be possible using a related metal such as [[tin]].

Any such catalyst would need to be nonreactive chemically but have properties that affect one mechanism but not the others, and also not interfere with subsequent annealing and oxygenation steps nor change the lattice resonances excessively. A possible workaround for the issues discussed would be to use strong electrostatic fields to hold the molecules in place during one of the steps until the lattice is formed.{{original research inline|date=October 2020}}
<!--Also relevant to the above discussion:<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://phys.org/news/2020-02-quasi-particle-pi-ton.html |title = New quasi-particle discovered: Introducing the Pi-ton}}</ref> which suggests tentatively that a sufficiently complex lattice with the right internal geometry could indeed superconduct well above the "official" maximum ever observed for cuprates, 153 K, if indeed flowing bipolarons composed of two electrons and two holes are able to sustain a [[supercurrent]].<ref>{{cite web |title=New advance in superconductors with 'twist' in rhombohedral graphite |url=https://phys.org/news/2020-08-advance-superconductors-rhombohedral-graphite.html |website=phys.org |language=en |date=August 2020}}</ref>-->

Some research efforts are currently moving towards [[Ternary compound|ternary]] [[Polyhydride#Superconduction|superhydrides]], where it has been predicted that {{chem|[[Lithium|Li]]|2|[[Magnesium|Mg]]|[[Hydrogen|H]]|16}} ([[bilithium magnesium hexadecahydride]]) would have a {{abbr|''T''<sub>c</sub>|Critical temperature}} of {{convert|473|K|°C}} at 250 GPa<ref>{{cite journal
 |title=Route to a Superconducting Phase above Room Temperature in Electron-Doped Hydride Compounds under High Pressure
 |date=August 26, 2019
 |journal=Physical Review Letters
 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.123.097001
 |quote=The recent theory-orientated discovery of record high-temperature superconductivity ({{abbr|''T''<sub>c</sub>|Critical temperature}}∼250 K) in sodalitelike clathrate LaH<sub>10</sub> is an important advance toward room-temperature superconductors. Here, we identify an alternative clathrate structure in ternary {{chem|[[Lithium|Li]]|2|[[Magnesium|Mg]]|[[Hydrogen|H]]|16}} with a remarkably high estimated ''T''<sub>c</sub> of ∼473 K at 250 GPa, which may allow us to obtain room-temperature or even higher-temperature superconductivity.|last1=Sun

 |last2=Lv

 |first3=Yu
 |last4=Liu
 |first4=Hanyu
 |last5=Ma

 |volume=123

 |pages=097001
 |pmid=31524448
 |bibcode=2019PhRvL.123i7001S
 |s2cid=202123043
 |url=https://physics.aps.org/featured-article-pdf/10.1103/PhysRevLett.123.097001
 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web
 |url=https://www.chemistryworld.com/news/the-race-is-on-to-make-the-first-room-temperature-superconductor/4010591.article
 |title=The race is on to make the first room temperature superconductor
 |last=Extance
 |first=Andy
 |date=November 1, 2019
 |website=www.chemistryworld.com
 |publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry
 |access-date=December 30, 2019
 |quote=In August, Ma and colleagues published a study that showed the promise of ternary superhydrides. They predicted that {{chem|[[Lithium|Li]]|2|[[Magnesium|Mg]]|[[Hydrogen|H]]|16}} would have a {{abbr|''T''<sub>c</sub>|Critical temperature}} of 473 [[Kelvin|K]] at 250 [[Pascal (unit)|GPa]], far in excess of room temperature.}}</ref> (much hotter than what is normally considered room temperature).

On the side of binary superhydrides, it has been predicted that {{chem|[[Scandium|Sc]]|[[Hydrogen|H]]|12}} ([[scandium dodedecahydride]]) would exhibit superconductivity at room temperature – {{abbr|''T''<sub>c</sub>|Critical temperature}} between {{convert|333|K|°C}} and {{convert|398|K|°C}} – under a pressure expected not to exceed 100 [[Pascal (unit)|GPa]].<ref>{{cite arXiv
